rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 10–28
rsbNotes.text:
10:1–28:27 The Divided Kingdom. In this section the writer makes use of 1 Kin. 12–2 Kin. 17. His record of the period of the divided monarchy does not rehearse the harsh condemnation of the northern tribes found in Kings, focusing instead on events in Judah where the temple was and the Davidic king lived. Throughout this section, the writer reports how the conditions in the kingdom depended on the nation’s faithfulness to God. As readers considered these events, they could see clearly the choices for blessing and curse in their own day.

In telling about Rehoboam’s kingship, the writer makes broad use of Kings (cf. 10:1–11:4 with 1 Kin. 12:1–24; 12:9–16 with 1 Kin. 14:21, 25–31), while presenting the material in accord with his own theological understanding and emphasis. The account is presented in two parts (chs. 10; 11 and 12:1–14), each part narrating a problematic situation, prophetic encounter, and divine blessing. The conclusion is a notice of his wars with Jeroboam and his death (12:15, 16). The chapters impress on the readers God’s curse against pride and infidelity and the benefits of living in humility and obedience to the prophetic word (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26
rsbNotes.text: 26:1–23 The historian who composed Chronicles adds a long section (vv. 5–20) to the brief notices about Uzziah in 2 Kings 14 and 15. His account is in four stages: rise to power (vv. 1–2), obedience and blessing (vv. 3–15), disobedience and curse (vv. 16–20), and summary and death (vv. 22, 23).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:1
rsbNotes.text: 26:1 Uzziah. Uzziah reigned 792/91–740/39 b.c. In 2 Kings he is frequently, but not always, called Azariah.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:4
rsbNotes.text: 26:4 according to . . . his father Amaziah. The historian compares Uzziah with his father, whose reign was also divided between blessing and curse.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:5
rsbNotes.text:
26:5 seek God . . . sought the Lord. See note 7:14.

in the days of Zechariah. An unknown royal adviser. It is unlikely that this is the person named in Is. 8:2, since “in the days of” suggests that Zechariah died during Uzziah’s reign and could not have been an adviser to his grandson. Joash was obedient as long as Jehoiada was alive, and Uzziah did well under Zechariah’s tutelage (24:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:6–15
rsbNotes.text: 26:6–15 Uzziah was blessed in international conflict (vv. 6–8), domestic affairs (vv. 9, 10), and military strength (vv. 11–15).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:7
rsbNotes.text: 26:7 Meunites. Uzziah’s blessing recalls Jehoshaphat’s victory (20:1–30).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:8
rsbNotes.text: 26:8 Ammonites. See note 1 Chr. 19:1.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:9
rsbNotes.text: 26:9 Uzziah built. A reversal of the destruction in Amaziah’s defeat (25:23). See note 1 Chr. 11:5.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:13
rsbNotes.text: 26:13 307,500. For the large number, see note 1 Chr. 12:23.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:16–20
rsbNotes.text: 26:16–20 This episode shows God’s judgment against Uzziah’s pride. As with Rehoboam (12:1), initial success led to disregard for God and His law. Uzziah’s leprosy is mentioned only briefly in 2 Kin. 15:5.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:16
rsbNotes.text: 26:16 when he was strong. Moses warned Israel to be careful not to let success make them proud and rely on themselves rather than on God (Deut. 8:10–18).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:17
rsbNotes.text: 26:17 Azariah. An otherwise unknown priest. He and eighty courageous priests delivered God’s judgment to Uzziah. The writer of Chronicles highlights the role of priests as instructors of royalty for a third time (24:2 and note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:18
rsbNotes.text: 26:18 for the priests. Burning incense was restricted to the priests in Mosaic legislation (Ex. 30:7–9; Num. 16:39, 40). See “Christians and Civil Government” at Rom. 13:1.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:21
rsbNotes.text: 26:21 excluded from the house of the Lord. Uzziah was quarantined and kept out of the temple, in agreement with the Law of Moses (Lev. 13:46; Num. 5:1–4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:22
rsbNotes.text: 26:22 Isaiah the prophet . . . wrote. See Introduction to 1 Chronicles: Author.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 26:23
rsbNotes.text: 26:23 in the burial field. Uzziah was buried away from the royal family in relative dishonor because of the curse of leprosy.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 27
rsbNotes.text: 27:1–9 In contrast to the records from Joash to Uzziah, where each reign has a balance of obedience and disobedience (22:10–24:27 note), the writer’s evaluation of Jotham is fully positive. This is followed with a negative treatment of Ahaz (ch. 28). Chronicles points out that faithfulness to God is the way to success in construction projects and military conflict.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 27:1
rsbNotes.text: 27:1 Jotham . . . sixteen years. Reigned 750–732 b.c. Jotham reigned during the period of his father Uzziah’s leprosy (750–740 b.c.), and had co-regency with his son Ahaz (735–732 b.c.). For six years he was the sole monarch. The figure “sixteen years” here and in v. 8 probably refers to his co-regency with his father and his independent reign. Adding his four years with Ahaz brings the total to twenty years (2 Kin. 15:30).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 27:2
rsbNotes.text:
27:2 did not enter the temple. Jotham did not violate priestly regulations as Uzziah had done (26:18 note).

the people still followed corrupt practices. The historian explains that the people and not Jotham were guilty of continuing corruption. (cf. 2 Kin. 15:35).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 27:5–6
rsbNotes.text: 27:5, 6 This record of victory over the Ammonites highlights God’s approval of Jotham.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 27:7
rsbNotes.text: 27:7 in the Book of the Kings. See Introduction to 1 Chronicles: Author.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28
rsbNotes.text: 28:1–27 The account of Ahaz in 2 Kin. 16 is supplemented in 2 Chronicles. Ahaz’s reign contrasts sharply with his father’s kingdom (ch. 27 note), and the account focuses on how infidelity leads to military defeat.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:1
rsbNotes.text: 28:1 Ahaz. Ahaz reigned together with Jotham 735–732 b.c., and then as sole monarch for sixteen years, 732–716 b.c. If he was twenty when he took office, he was thirty-six when he died, and he would have been only eleven when his son Hezekiah was born (29:1). Some ancient sources give the figure “twenty-five” instead of “twenty” for his age at succession.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:3
rsbNotes.text: 28:3 burned his sons. Ahaz’s apostasy was so complete that he practiced human sacrifice. See Lev. 18:21; Deut. 12:31; 18:10; 2 Kin. 16:3; 17:17; 21:6; 23:10; 2 Chr. 33:6; Ps. 106:37, 38; Is. 57:5; Jer. 7:30, 31; 19:5; 32:35; Ezek. 16:20, 21; Mic. 6:7.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:5–15
rsbNotes.text: 28:5–15 Ahaz is defeated in battle as a divine judgment on his flagrant apostasy (v. 5).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:5
rsbNotes.text: 28:5 king of Syria . . . king of Israel. Rezin (king of Syria) and Pekah (king of Israel) joined forces against Ahaz (2 Kin. 16:5, 6; Is. 7:1–17).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:9
rsbNotes.text: 28:9 Samaria. Turning from his usual focus on the southern kingdom (Judah), the historian reports that citizens of Samaria, capital of the northern kingdom, obeyed when a prophet spoke to them. This obedience was an instructive contrast to the apostasy of Judah, the southern kingdom.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:21
rsbNotes.text:
28:21 took . . . from the house of the Lord. See note 16:2.

did not help him. Tiglath-pileser of Assyria (745–727 b.c.) gave some temporary relief to Judah from the threats of Syria and Israel (2 Kin. 16:7–9), but Judah became subservient to Assyria.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:25
rsbNotes.text: 28:25 made high places. See note 21:11.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:26
rsbNotes.text: 28:26 the Book of the Kings. See Introduction to 1 Chronicles: Author.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 28:27
rsbNotes.text: 28:27 not . . . tombs. See note 21:19.
